 It would be best if the libs took the west - far fewer people would have to move for one thing. For another, having conservatives in the west wouldn't work, because their pollution would drift east, and cause too much problem for the liberals environmental programs. 
 
 I don't think the Mississippi river would be a good border - to be an equal divide area-wise it would have to split the Dakotas, Texas, etc. There would have to be a wall, probably a double wall with a huge buffer zone, staffed with conservative sharp shooters. (no liberal sharpshooters would be necessary - illegal immigration attempts would only be a one-way problem - no conservatives would want to cross this border) 
 
 Think how it would be then - the east could actually return to the constitutional principles of small government, and states rights. They could actually build bridges without having to wait 10 years on environmental studies. The 10 commandments would be displayed! "You don't work - you don't eat" would be the order of the day. Those unable to work would be provided for by the religious community. People like Romney, McCain, Palin, Thompson would be the leaders. There would be a strong military, just like the constitution prescribes. 
 
 In the west, they wouldn't need state governments - everything would be decided by a massive federal government. Jeremiah Wright, Barney Frank, Nancy Pelosi, Obama, Biden, the list of impressive leaders would be long. They could administer free health care for everyone, design smart pedal-cars for everyone, and pretty well tell everyone just how they'll live and what they'll do. They could save lots of money by having little or no military, they could beg the east to help them out with aggressive enemies whenever necessary. They could forget about oil and build lots of windmills. They would have all the Mexican border - they could welcome immigrants with open arms! 
 
 It would be a dream come true for both sides!

United we stand, divided we fall.
 
 And those who seek to divide us... practically work for our enemies.

 -Mosheh Thezion emoticon_angry

 
 
 
 You seem genuinely angry at the thought - why? South America is divided into several relatively small countries, as is Europe. (for the record, I've looked over your website, I'd vote for you in a heartbeat) But you could never be elected, because only a minority of people in the U.S. today have any respect for the Constitution. 
 
 It's not politically correct to bash the U.S. Constitution - that's the only reason it's not constantly done, by U.S. citizens and politicians alike. Most people realize something that few will ever actually say - the U.S. Constitution is not a prescription for a heaven on earth, for a perfect society. It simply does not suit a lot of people. Many people don't care much about liberty - they'll gladly accept being told what to do, where to live, where to "work" (put in time) if it gets them something for nothing, an easy, idle lifestyle, etc. Is it wrong to think about finding a way to separate them from those who value liberty? 
 
 The 'something for nothing' attitude has been on the increase since church and state were separated in 1947. Is it really surprising? It goes along perfectly with the several proclamations by prominent people at the founding of the U.S. - that this system of government only works with a moral people. 
 
 If the U.S. continues on its current economic path, it's not a question of if, it's a question of when there won't be liberty for anyone, except for a very small group of elites. There were political divides in the U.S. 100, or 150 years ago, but not to the extent there are today. There has never been such a large percentage of U.S. citizens who demand that some routine living expenses be paid for by someone else. It has not a thing to do with the spirit of the U.S. Constitution. 
 
 Of course I was being facetious in my post #25 for effect, but don't you think a peaceful divide would be a better alternative to a really ugly conflict as a result of staying united? To me, the ugliest part of U.S. history was the period between 1860 -1865. That was largely a result of a disagreement of the divide itself. I believe the time could come when the intensity of a disagreement of our current unification could reach those heights. If a divide would avoid a bloody conflict, would you agree with it?
Iuris

Well, if you do split up, I want to see a nice civil war. I want to see how an invulnerable Abrams fares against killer A10, or an Apache Hellfire.
 
 Jokes and military toy enthusiasm aside, the US has no idea how well off it is by having a whole continent to itself.
